content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: How many results are there for a search on Coursera for Machine Learning, then filtered by Credit Eligible and 1-4 Years duration?  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open search box.
Action: Click [305]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search textbox is focused within combobox; type the query Machine Learning.
Action: Type [2333]; Machine Learning
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open filters panel.
Action: Click [2950]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to expand Duration section to select 1‑4 Years.
Action: Click [3290]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Click Show More in Duration to reveal longer ranges including 1‑4 Years.
Action: Click [3359]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Maybe the Show More button isn’t currently interactable; scroll the page a bit to ensure it is fully in view, then try again.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Attempt to expand more duration options by clicking “Show More”.
Action: Click [3359]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to ensure “Show More” is fully visible; scrolling down may enable the click.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Try clicking the “Show More” button within Duration to reveal additional options (including 1‑4 Years).
Action: Click [3359]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Bring “Show More” fully into view within the Duration region by scrolling inside that region, then we can click it.
Action: Scroll [3300]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Click the “Show More” button inside Duration to reveal further duration options such as “1‑4 Years”.
Action: Click [3359]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Select the 1‑4 Years duration filter checkbox.
Action: Click [5454]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate and apply the “Credit Eligible” filter; scroll the filters panel further down to reveal that section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Credit‑eligible filter likely resides above Duration in the filter list; scroll upward to locate it.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to continue scrolling downward within the filters list to look for a “Credit Eligible” section that we can check.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Credit Eligible filter likely is above the current “Duration” section in the filter list; need to scroll upward in the main window to reach it.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate the “Credit Eligible” filter, which is likely above the currently visible “Duration” section, so scroll farther up the filters pane.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The Credit Eligible filter seems to be above, so need to scroll further up the filters panel to bring earlier filter headings into view.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reach the earlier filters above “Duration”, so scroll the page further upward.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reach any earlier filter section (possibly Credit Eligible) positioned above Duration; continue scrolling page upward.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The filter sections continue below “Educator”; likely “Credit Eligible” is further down, so scroll downward to reveal additional filter headings.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Credit Eligible” option is likely further down inside the Filters panel itself, which is probably a scrollable region. I should scroll within that Filters region rather than the main window to reveal more filter categories.
Action: Scroll [2938]; down

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to continue scrolling the main page downward to reveal further filter sections after “Educator”, where the “Credit Eligible” filter should appear.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate “Credit Eligible” filter; likely sits in earlier sections above Duration. The filter list probably has internal scroll, so scrolling the window hasn’t moved within that list. I should scroll inside the filter list region (parent of Duration heading) instead of whole window. I’ll attempt to scroll that region upward.
Action: Scroll [2911]; up

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Continue scrolling the main window upward so that any earlier filter sections (where “Credit Eligible” should be) come into view.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Credit Eligible” filter is probably located further down in the filter list, beneath the “Educator” section that’s now visible. I should keep scrolling the main page downward to reach additional filter sections.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Likely the “Credit Eligible” filter is above the “Duration” section or near the very top of the results page; scrolling the window upward should reveal it.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
